sn48.58:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate sūkarakhatāyaṃ.
sn48.58:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain in the Boar’s Cave.

sn48.58:1.2.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:
sn48.58:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta:

sn48.58:1.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, sāriputta, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti?
sn48.58:1.3.eng: “Sāriputta, considering what benefit does a mendicant with defilements ended, while still alive, continue to act with utmost deference for the Realized One or his instructions?”

sn48.58:1.4.pli: “Anuttarañhi, bhante, yogakkhemaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti.
sn48.58:1.4.eng: “Sir, it is considering the supreme sanctuary from the yoke that a mendicant with defilements ended, while still alive, continues to act with utmost deference for the Realized One or his instructions.”

sn48.58:1.6.pli: Anuttarañhi, sāriputta, yogakkhemaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattati.
sn48.58:1.6.eng: For it is considering the supreme sanctuary from the yoke that a mendicant whose defilements are ended, while still alive, continues to act with utmost deference for the Realized One or his instructions.

sn48.58:2.1.pli: Katamo ca, sāriputta, anuttaro yogakkhemo yaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti?
sn48.58:2.1.eng: And what is that supreme sanctuary from the yoke?”

sn48.58:2.2.pli: “Idha, bhante, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu saddhindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ,
sn48.58:2.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant with defilements ended develops the faculties of faith,

sn48.58:2.6.eng: and wisdom, which lead to peace and awakening.

sn48.58:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhante, anuttaro yogakkhemo yaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti.
sn48.58:2.7.eng: It is considering this supreme sanctuary from the yoke that a mendicant with defilements ended, while still alive, continues to act with utmost deference for the Realized One or his instructions.”

sn48.58:2.9.pli: Eso hi, sāriputta, anuttaro yogakkhemo yaṃ sampassamāno khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatīti.
sn48.58:2.9.eng: For this is that supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn48.58:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, sāriputta, paramanipaccakāro yaṃ khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti?
sn48.58:3.1.eng: And what is that utmost deference that a mendicant with defilements ended, while still alive, continues to show towards the Realized One or his instructions?”

sn48.58:3.2.pli: “Idha, bhante, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu satthari sagāravo viharati sappatisso, dhamme sagāravo viharati sappatisso, saṅghe sagāravo viharati sappatisso, sikkhāya sagāravo viharati sappatisso, samādhismiṃ sagāravo viharati sappatisso.
sn48.58:3.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant with defilements ended maintains respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and immersion.

sn48.58:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhante, paramanipaccakāro yaṃ khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti.

sn48.58:3.5.pli: Eso hi, sāriputta, paramanipaccakāro yaṃ khīṇāsavo bhikkhu tathāgate vā tathāgatasāsane vā paramanipaccakāraṃ pavattamāno pavattatī”ti.
sn48.58:3.5.eng: For this is that utmost deference that a mendicant with defilements ended, while still alive, continues to show towards the Realized One or his instructions.”

sn48.59:1.2.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anuppannāni uppajjanti, nāññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvā arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
sn48.59:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, these five faculties don’t arise to be developed and cultivated except when a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has appeared.

sn48.59:1.4.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.59:1.5.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anuppannāni uppajjanti, nāññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvā arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
sn48.59:1.5.eng: These five faculties don’t arise to be developed and cultivated except when a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has appeared.”

sn48.6:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.6:1.4.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
sn48.6:1.4.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these five faculties.

sn48.6:1.5.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.6:1.5.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.6:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.6:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the gratification, drawback, and escape when it comes to these five faculties.

sn48.6:2.2.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā; te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.6:2.2.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.60:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anuppannāni uppajjanti, nāññatra sugatavinayā.
sn48.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five faculties don’t arise to be developed and cultivated apart from the Holy One’s training.

sn48.60:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.60:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anuppannāni uppajjanti, nāññatra sugatavinayā”ti.
sn48.60:1.4.eng: These five faculties don’t arise to be developed and cultivated apart from the Holy One’s training.”

sn48.61:1.2.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni saṃyojanappahānāya saṃvattanti.
sn48.61:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to giving up the fetters.

sn48.61:1.4.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.61:1.5.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni saṃyojanappahānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn48.61:1.5.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to giving up the fetters.”

sn48.62:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anusayasamugghātāya saṃvattanti.
sn48.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to uprooting the underlying tendencies.

sn48.62:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.62:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni anusayasamugghātāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn48.62:1.4.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to uprooting the underlying tendencies.”

sn48.63:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni addhānapariññāya saṃvattanti.
sn48.63:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to the complete understanding of the course of time.

sn48.63:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.63:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni addhānapariññāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn48.63:1.4.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to the complete understanding of the course of time.”

sn48.64:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattanti.
sn48.64:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to the ending of defilements.

sn48.64:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.64:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattantīti.
sn48.64:1.4.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to the ending of defilements.”

sn48.64:2.1.pli: Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, indriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni saṃyojanappahānāya saṃvattanti, anusayasamugghātāya saṃvattanti, addhānapariññāya saṃvattanti, āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattanti.
sn48.64:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to giving up the fetters, uprooting the underlying tendencies, completely understanding the course of time, and ending the defilements.

sn48.64:2.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.64:2.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni saṃyojanappahānāya saṃvattanti, anusayasamugghātāya saṃvattanti, addhānapariññāya saṃvattanti, āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn48.64:2.4.eng: When these five faculties are developed and cultivated they lead to giving up the fetters, uprooting the underlying tendencies, completely understanding the course of time, and ending the defilements.”

sn48.65:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.65:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
sn48.65:1.5.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these five faculties, one of two results can be expected:

sn48.65:1.6.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
sn48.65:1.6.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

sn48.66:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.66:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā satta phalā sattānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
sn48.66:1.5.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these five faculties, seven fruits and benefits can be expected.

sn48.66:1.7.eng: They attain enlightenment early on in this very life.

sn48.66:1.8.pli: no ce diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ ārādheti, atha maraṇakāle aññaṃ ārādheti.
sn48.66:1.8.eng: If not, they attain enlightenment at the time of death.

sn48.66:1.9.pli: No ce diṭṭheva dhamme aññaṃ ārādheti, no ce maraṇakāle aññaṃ ārādheti, atha pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti,
sn48.66:1.9.eng: If not, with the ending of the five lower fetters, they’re extinguished between one life and the next …

sn48.66:1.13.eng: they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

sn48.66:1.14.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā ime satta phalā sattānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
sn48.66:1.14.eng: Because of developing and cultivating these five faculties, these seven fruits and benefits can be expected.”

sn48.67:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci jambudīpakā rukkhā, jambū tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.67:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, of all the trees in the Black Plum Tree Land, the black plum is said to be the best.

sn48.67:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.67:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.67:1.3.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.67:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.

sn48.67:1.8.pli: paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.67:1.8.eng: and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.67:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci jambudīpakā rukkhā, jambū tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.67:1.9.eng: Of all the trees in the Black Plum Tree Land, the black plum is said to be the best.

sn48.67:1.10.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.67:1.10.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.68:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ rukkhā, pārichattako tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, of all the trees belonging to the gods of the thirty-three, the Shady Orchid Tree is said to be the best.

sn48.68:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.68:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.68:1.3.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.68:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.

sn48.68:1.8.pli: paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.68:1.8.eng: and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.68:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ rukkhā, pārichattako tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.68:1.9.eng: Of all the trees belonging to the gods of the thirty-three, the Shady Orchid Tree is said to be the best.

sn48.68:1.10.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.68:1.10.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.69:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci asurānaṃ rukkhā, cittapāṭali tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, of all the trees belonging to the titans, the vivid patala is said to be the best.

sn48.69:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.69:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.69:1.3.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.69:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati …pe… paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.69:1.4.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.69:1.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci asurānaṃ rukkhā, cittapāṭali tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.69:1.5.eng: Of all the trees belonging to the titans, the vivid patala is said to be the best.

sn48.69:1.6.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.69:1.6.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.7:1.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā saddhindriyaṃ nappajānanti, saddhindriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, saddhindriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, saddhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;
sn48.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand the faculty of faith, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.7:1.2.eng: They don’t understand the faculty of energy …

sn48.7:1.5.pli: paññindriyaṃ nappajānanti, paññindriyasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, paññindriyanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, paññindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti,
sn48.7:1.5.eng: wisdom, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.7:1.6.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn48.7:1.6.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn48.7:2.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā saddhindriyaṃ pajānanti, saddhindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, saddhindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, saddhindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti;
sn48.7:2.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the faculty of faith, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.7:2.2.pli: vīriyindriyaṃ pajānanti, vīriyindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, vīriyindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, vīriyindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti;
sn48.7:2.2.eng: They do understand the faculty of energy …

sn48.7:2.5.pli: paññindriyaṃ pajānanti, paññindriyasamudayaṃ pajānanti, paññindriyanirodhaṃ pajānanti, paññindriyanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti,
sn48.7:2.5.eng: wisdom, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn48.7:2.6.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn48.7:2.6.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn48.70:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci supaṇṇānaṃ rukkhā, kūṭasimbalī tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.70:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, of all the trees belonging to the phoenixes, the red silk-cotton tree is said to be the best.

sn48.70:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāya.
sn48.70:1.2.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.

sn48.70:1.3.eng: And what are the qualities that lead to awakening?

sn48.70:1.4.pli: Saddhindriyaṃ, bhikkhave, bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati …pe… paññindriyaṃ bodhipakkhiyo dhammo, taṃ bodhāya saṃvattati.
sn48.70:1.4.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom are qualities that lead to awakening, in that they lead to becoming awakened.

sn48.70:1.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci supaṇṇānaṃ rukkhā, kūṭasimbalī tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
sn48.70:1.5.eng: Of all the trees belonging to the phoenixes, the red silk-cotton tree is said to be the best.

sn48.70:1.6.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye keci bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, paññindriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ—bodhāyā”ti.
sn48.70:1.6.eng: In the same way, the faculty of wisdom is said to be the best of the qualities that lead to awakening in terms of becoming awakened.”

sn48.71-82:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn48.71-82:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn48.71-82:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn48.71-82:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant developing and cultivating the five faculties slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn48.71-82:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?

sn48.71-82:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhindriyaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
sn48.71-82:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the faculties of faith,

sn48.71-82:1.8.pli: paññindriyaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn48.71-82:1.8.eng: and wisdom, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn48.71-82:1.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn48.71-82:1.9.eng: That’s how a mendicant developing and cultivating the five faculties slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn48.71-82:2.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn48.71-82:2.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn48.71-82:2.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn48.8:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.8:1.4.eng: And where should the faculty of faith be seen?

sn48.8:1.5.eng: In the four factors of stream-entry.

sn48.8:1.7.eng: And where should the faculty of energy be seen?

sn48.8:1.10.eng: And where should the faculty of mindfulness be seen?

sn48.8:1.11.eng: In the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn48.8:1.13.eng: And where should the faculty of immersion be seen?

sn48.8:1.16.eng: And where should the faculty of wisdom be seen?

sn48.83-92:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on diligence at SN 45.139–148.)

sn48.83-92:2.1.eng: The Realized One, footprint, roof peak,

sn48.9:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.9:1.4.eng: And what is the faculty of faith?

sn48.9:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
sn48.9:1.5.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

sn48.9:1.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti—
sn48.9:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn48.9:1.7.eng: This is called the faculty of faith.

sn48.9:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of energy?

sn48.9:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu—
sn48.9:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

sn48.9:2.3.eng: This is called the faculty of energy.

sn48.9:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of mindfulness?

sn48.9:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā—
sn48.9:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

sn48.9:3.3.eng: This is called the faculty of mindfulness.

sn48.9:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of immersion?

sn48.9:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vossaggārammaṇaṃ karitvā labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassa ekaggataṃ—
sn48.9:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple, relying on letting go, gains immersion, gains unification of mind.

sn48.9:4.3.eng: This is called the faculty of immersion.

sn48.9:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of wisdom?

sn48.9:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya, sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
sn48.9:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn48.9:5.3.eng: This is called the faculty of wisdom.

sn48.93-104:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on hard work at SN 45.149–160.)

sn48.93-104:2.2.eng: a tree, a pot, and a spike,

sn48.93-104:2.3.eng: the atmosphere, and two on clouds,

sn48.93-104:2.4.eng: a ship, a guest house, and a river.
